utterances: So this is research he's done in Africa?
Yes, in Kenya.
And what he was looking at are these habitats that they have there called dambos.
They're basically just low-lying areas.
And when it rains, and it rains for a long time, these dambos flood and you get giant puddles.
And you know, when you have puddles, you have mosquitoes.
Can you explain how we get from research in Africa on the ground to weather satellites at NASA?
Well, that is actually what I went out to NASA to find out.
Dr. Linthicum had had colleagues that worked on weather satellite imagery and he realized that you could use some of the satellite data to predict climate patterns, to predict rainfall.
So when I went out to NASA I spoke to a scientist Assaf Anyamba.
Dr. Anyamba works on a lot of these data.
And he told me that the two most important factors in predicting rainfall are sea surface temperatures and cloud cover.
Which they can all get from the weather satellite.
Right.
And that's the kind of thing you can get from a weather satellite.
So when you have warm ocean surfaces in the Indian Ocean and the Pacific Ocean, and you have a lot of clouds, that's almost a perfect predictor of heavy rains.
And he said it's a pattern that you see a lot with an El Nino.

I usually like to use this whole idea that when you have the Indian Ocean and the Pacific dancing to the same tune, you are going to generate enough rainfall to flood the dambo habitats in East Africa.
And basically, that is an early indicator of the disease.
Thank you.
I know exactly what you're saying, and I am not kidding, I just said that to somebody this morning.
That at least, at the very least, we're talking about some of the challenges, especially with autism.
I think, basically what's happening is, had we had these challenges 20 years ago, we would had to have had little access to any resources.
And it would have been a much more difficult landscape.
But now we have the internet, we have people more open to talking about certain things, we have more information.
And I think it is a positive time.
There're still people out there struggling with it, but the positive is that, yes, it's a very good time to talk about, or if you get this diagnosis of autism, it's not the end of the world.
There are treatments that we didn't even know about when we got our diagnosis, you know, eight or nine years ago.
So there's some positive things happening right now.
You've also been able in the past to turn some of the challenges that you've faced into outreach to other people.
And I'm thinking of your father, who passed away from Parkinson's, which degenerates the nervous system and eventually causes death.
And I'm sure it was horrific to watch him go through that, but at the same time you were able to take that and turn it into a foundation.
Tell us a little bit about how you decided to take the inspiration from your father's passing and turn it into something positive.
Well, actually, the inspiration came before he passed away, when he was diagnosed with Parkinson's disease.
He was only in his 40s.
I was a freshman in college, and I was wondering what this limp was, he was limping.
And he - my father was the original Gordon on ""Sesame Street,"" and if you're sort of between 30 and 40-plus, you remember him as the very original Gordon.
And he's just a brilliant man.
He went on to write and produce ""The Cosby Show"" for the whole run of the show, and wrote a lot of sitcoms.

And one of the sitcoms that he was a writer on was ""Sanford & Son."" And I remember being at Sarah Lawrence College in the early '80s, and watching my daddy - he dropped me of at school, and he walked away from me and he was limping.
And I said, hey, Dad, why are you walking like Fred Sanford?
And my dad, who was very, very funny and quick on his feet, was saying, listen, don't worry about me.
You just do your studies and pay attention in class or you'll be running a junkyard, too.

And we laughed about it and he kind of played it off, but when I came home for Christmas that year, he had a case of Bell's palsy and his face was slouchy and that's when we got the diagnosis that he had Parkinson's.
He was only 46 years old.
So for about ten years, I was sort of in denial, in this really ugly slump about the situation.
But when I met my husband, he told me that we need to help people with this disease.
So that's how the HollyRod Foundation got started, and we basically help elevate the quality of life of people with Parkinson's.

And then - as we got the diagnosis for autism, we sort of incorporated that within our mission and we have what's called HollyRod 4 Kids, where we help raise money for the quality of life of children as well.
All right.
Before we let you go, I have to ask about ""21 Jump Street.
(Soundbite of laughter)

There - you have done some, you know, you've done so many amazing things in life, you know, playing Diana Ross, all these things that people would consider a dream, but at, you know, being in the demo that I am in...
Yeah.
Which is the same demo you mentioned around ""Sesame Street,"" I totally adored ""21 Jump Street."" What did you learn from doing that?
And do people still come up to you and talk to you about it?
Everywhere I go.
Everywhere I go someone remembers ""21 Jump Street,"" and then, of course, there are the younger, younger generation, like the 'tween-set, like my kids, it's not really on their radar.
When they think of Johnny Depp, they think of, you know, the whole ""Pirates"" series, and they are like, wow, you were in a movie with Captain - you were in a TV show with Captain Jack Sparrow?
And so people still really love it and the - I really felt like we were a groundbreaking show.
We shot everything on location in Canada.
It was just a young, heady time.
We had everyone on the show before they were stars from Brad Pitt to Jada Pinkett-Smith, and many others, and it was, I believe, a show that was ahead of its time.
One more thing.
Your radio show?
What's it like doing a radio show with your husband?
Well, radio, I have to say, is a little different animal than TV.
I thought it was going to be super easy.
We do it out of our house.
It's on XM 156.
We do - we're on a show called ""Meet the Peetes"" with Oprah & Friends and we talk about everything from politics to parenting.
I thought, oh, I can roll out of bed, don't have to put on any lashes, no makeup, lipstick.
Just roll out of bed and do this show.
But it's a lot more work than I thought.
You have to talk to your husband every day for an hour and we have to be getting along, too.
If we're...
(Soundbite of laughter)
If we're not getting along that day, it makes for a long hour.
So the wonderful part of it...
Hey, Mommy.
Well, just like I'm talking to you now, the wonderful part is that we do it from home...
(Unintelligible).
And my three-year-old can walk in, as he just walked in...
(Soundbite of laughter)
(Unintelligible).
And it's one of those really interesting, very interesting things.
But I'm loving radio and I encourage people to check us out on XM 156.
Mommy, hi?
Ah, can you say hi?
Sure, say hi.
Hi.
Hi.
How are you doing?
Say, I'm Roman.
My name's Roman.
It's good to talk to you.
Have a great day.
Yeah.
Say, see you later.

Actress Holly Robinson Peete wrote the introduction for ""Book of Life: Making Your Best Days Happen."" She's also the cofounder of the HollyRod Foundation, which deals with Parkinson's disease awareness.
Holly joined me from her home studio in Los Angeles.
This is Day to Day.
I'm Alex Chadwick.
I'm Madeleine Brand.
Coming up, two years can seem like a long time before babies begin talking, and so babies' sign language has sprung up.
But does it work?
We'll find out in a moment.
First, you can watch U.S.
swimmer Michael Phelps compete in the 200 meter individual medley tonight.
He's going for his sixth Beijing gold medal.
Maybe even more amazing, 41-year-old Dara Torres returns to the Olympic pool ready to swim against competitors' decades younger.
You can see her tonight as well.
From Beijing, NPR's Howard Berkes reports.
Dara Torres has trouble acting her age.
After four Olympics, ten Olympic medals, two long retirements, the birth of a daughter, and 34 years in the pool, she's swimming faster now than she did at half this age.
I am looking forward to standing up and competing.
I just want to go out there for those 40-something-year-olds and show that age is just a number and go out there and have fun.
That was Torres before her first Olympic final in Beijing, where she and three teammates woe silver medals in the 400 meter freestyle relay.
That made her the oldest swimming medalist in history.
At 41, she's the great hope of the gray generation, pushing life's prime time to the limit, and symbolizing what's possible despite age.
I find adults coming up to me and actually, not asking for autographs, but talking to me and having long conversations and hearing about how they've been inspired.
And I tell them I've been inspired, and it's just kind of nice to have a different age group following you, and hopefully, I represent them well.
Lean, tough, and taut, Torres works hard for that hard body, spending five days in the pool and four days in the gym every week.
There's also resistance stretching, where two trainers stretch and mash her muscles three time a week and before and after swimming.
Cynics suspect she gets artificial help from performance enhancing drugs.
Torres has volunteered for extra drug testing to show she's clean.
Coach Jack Bauerle explains her endurance this way.
